etymologies: mid 16th century: from Italian carnevale, carnovale, from medieval Latin carnelevamen, carnelevarium ‘Shrovetide’, from Latin caro, carn- ‘flesh’ + levare ‘put away’

definitions: a period of public revelry at a regular time each year, typically during the week before Lent in Roman Catholic countries, involving processions, music, dancing, and the use of masquerade

examples.text: the culmination of the week-long carnival
Mardi Gras is the last day of carnival

definitions: a public event or celebration, typically held outdoors and offering entertainment and exhibitions

examples.text: he helped judge the ice-sculpture contest at the college's winter carnival

shortDefinitions: public event or celebration held outdoors involving entertainment and processions

definitions: an exciting or riotous mixture of something

examples.text: the whole evening was a carnival of fun

shortDefinitions: exciting or riotous mixture of elements

definitions: a traveling amusement show or circus

examples.text: he worked at a carnival, climbing Ferris wheels and working 18-hour days
